description: Agentic Shopping Axiom Checker - 12 core beliefs for evaluating newsletter items through the lens of agentic commerce

axioms.title: Institutions matter more than intent
axioms.description: Platform rules, marketplace enforcement, and regulatory frameworks determine agentic shopping outcomes — not 'responsible AI commerce' rhetoric

axioms.title: Legitimacy is a hard constraint
axioms.description: Consumer trust and regulatory acceptance constrain what agentic shopping can achieve; backlash and loss of trust are predictable failure modes

axioms.title: Adaptability beats ambition
axioms.description: Agentic shopping systems that cannot be revised, killed, or reversed without humiliation will eventually rot; irreversibility is the enemy

axioms.title: Errors must be localized and costly
axioms.description: If agent purchasing failures are socialized, hidden, or narratively reframed, learning stops; someone must feel the downside of being wrong

axioms.title: Knowledge is dispersed; central intelligence is a liability
axioms.description: No single platform can reliably centralize all product, pricing, and preference knowledge; decentralized selection outperforms centralized foresight

axioms.title: Incentives overpower intentions every time
axioms.description: If an agentic shopping system rewards conversion, growth, or dominance, it will drift there regardless of stated consumer-first goals

axioms.title: Rules and markets beat ownership
axioms.description: Regulatory gravity, standard-setting, and market access matter more than owning the agent stack; leverage beats equity

axioms.title: Architecture determines sustainability
axioms.description: Energy, compute, and material costs of agentic commerce must be enforced at the design level or they will be externalized

axioms.title: AI should narrow the judgment-consequence distance
axioms.description: Agentic shopping becomes dangerous when it optimizes persuasion, hides accountability, or replaces human purchase intent with emergent behavior

axioms.title: Symbolism is stabilizing but non-operative
axioms.description: Ethics boards, responsible AI charters, and consumer protection pledges are decorative unless removing them would alter actual system behavior

axioms.title: Buy outcomes, not subsidize ambition
axioms.description: Demand-side mechanisms create discipline in agentic commerce; supply-side subsidies create capture; the state is a poor VC but a powerful customer

axioms.title: Most failures are structural, not ideological
axioms.description: Bad agentic shopping outcomes come from mismatched incentives, wrong abstraction level, or ignored second-order effects — not from malice or bad values

regions.label: United States
regions.context: Platform-dominated market; light-touch regulation; Big Tech controls agent infrastructure; consumer data as competitive asset; antitrust enforcement emerging but slow

regions.label: European Union
regions.context: Regulatory-first approach; AI Act, DMA, DSA as structural constraints; consumer protection tradition; interoperability mandates; smaller platform players; Brussels Effect as leverage

regions.label: China
regions.context: State-directed platform economy; super-apps as agent infrastructure; social credit integration; domestic data sovereignty; government-aligned AI development; massive scale advantage

regions.label: Rest of Asia
regions.context: Diverse regulatory landscapes; mobile-first commerce (Japan, Korea, SEA); super-app models (Grab, GoTo); emerging AI adoption; varying data protection maturity; cross-border complexity
